div.p: urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.1

This is the book they called the interrupted battle. For it being problematic abbreviates the narrative of the Achaeans. Dawn is called [yellow-veiled] the word κεκροπεπλος cannot be read from the text of the Upsilon 1.1 but is restored from an analogous scholion in the Venetus B and the Iliadic line, whenever there is much darkness, there is some light. As opposed to [being called] ροδοδακτυλος (rosy-fingered). The periphrasis is poetic. As [the poet] says day has come. εδκιδνατο is in the imperfect tense, because the earth being spherical, is not illuminated all at once.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.70

How does Zeus set down two fates/dooms as there is one fulfillment/end for each army? In these matters they say that πλειους is a logical arrangement of words: αἱ μὲν Ἀχαιῶν κῆρες (The fates of the Achaeans). Because there may be δυο (two) or πολλαι (many). Indeed I say that matters are twofold. But others it is "πλειονων" with the noun giving emphasis. Similarly in a change of case he [the poet] said πλεονας. It is a figure of speech, one of the measuring out together figures of speech. Death is said to be like burning. Therefore one is put to rest through fire. If it reveals/releases the soul as if it were . For one customarily searches for knowledge in oneself.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.33
He does not reveal his thoughts because he wishes to be an ally to the Trojans. But he orders them to hinder themselves in aiding both sides. She, understanding it, refuted his logic.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.114

In the line he has shown that it is expected that he [Sthenelos] be left behind. For he has not said previously where the charioteers were. They say that Sthenelos having been brought down from the walls was wounded with respect to his leg and because of this he did not fight but rather held the reins for Diomedes.

p.note: There are two scholion numbers, one written in the interior margin and one written before the scholion text

div.p: urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.112

It is economical for Nestor to mount the chariot of Diomedes, in order that he be persuaded to flee and to yield to the exhortations of Nestor. For he [Diomedes] could not be persuaded by Sthenelus. Whereas not in the lines above, was he [able] to urge him to mount the chariot.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.93

The epithet is used because of the retreat. For it is necessary for him to be such a soldier. For he is a farmer [as is seen] from the passage in which he knows well how to move the sickle in the grass and all the implements for farming. He is a ship-steerer because he keeps the sail straight (Odyssey 10.32). A carpenter, from the good condition of the stones. And from the skillful sawing of wood. A shipbuilder from the ship. A hunter from leading the hunting packs and from the knowledge of the mountains. A seer from the landing places. A cook from, as is necessary, roasting and cutting up. A doctor, from the passages in which he diagnoses sickness and cuts out arrows. A musician and a singer from beauty of his songs and speeches. A boxer and a wrestler from versatility and his wrestling grip. An archer, from the best ability to survey. A javelin-thrower, from the passage where he throws the spear well. An orator, from his persuasiveness. A general from his foresight and manly courage. A soldier from craftiness and great experience
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.233
Rather the full form αντα. As is preferable to Herodian as well. Indeed it is not αντι even though it seemed so to Aristarchus.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.208
He does not say, as is common, την δ’ ημειβετ’ επειτα. But on account of her harshness, he renounces her impudence.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.13

Tartarus is opposite to Olympus. For the one, "never shook with winds, nor with heavy rain" (Odyssey 6.43). And the other is chaotic and it seems to be cold, from which they say that to fall into Tartarus is to be violently cold. And the one is wholly shone upon and the other is cloudy
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.16

The heavens, as he [the poet] says, have three distinct parts. The lower air spans up to the clouds. Then the aether spans up to the visible places and the realm of Zeus. And in a similar way so it goes from the earth to Hades, from Hades to Tartarus. And so the earth is clearly as the middle center point. And it is right to say that it is as far beneath the earth as the earth is from heaven. And indeed perhaps he [the poet] calls it Hades because of the rulership of Hades.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.206-8.207

One ought to place the nu at the beginning of the line because the consonant is before the elision and is connected to the following vowel. But there is a full stop after the nu. For it should be placed between the syllable and between the elision. Often in the beginning of a line a full stop is placed poetically.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.261-8.266
The poet, reporting the flight of the Greeks, does not require many names. But now in the battle he recalls many of those who retreated.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.266

The poet makes a distinction because he is about to speak about him [Teucer]. But Odysseus is within rousing the soldiers. Thoas is also not mentioned and he [Thoas] is not entirely cowardly [either]. see Iliad 7.168
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.92
In the lines, it is apparent that Odysseus has also fled. Above mention is made of him, but Diomedes is always steadfast and he alone wishes to go nowhere.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.97

He did not hear because of the noise or he was not persuaded because of the crisis. For he flees with the Ajaxes and he does not want to wage war against the gods. For how is that cowardly? He is fleeing with everyone else. Because Diomedes would not have called out to him alone.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.178

From the one οὐδενόσωρα. Because such a compound also is rare. But I say it is [a compound] from the negation and the conjunction [δε] and because of the genitive ἑνὸς . But others preserve it as οὐδενὸς. But it is persuasive to remember that it is a recent work [i.e. the wall], when he [Hector] is greatly disparaging the action of the Achaeans.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.408
"to hinder" but the metaphor is taken from spears being struck against shields.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.150
t is εὐρεῖα instead of εὐρέως, and he says that death is better than disgrace.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.429

Whenever he [the poet] is looking at the reputation of the gods, then he says they would not be moved by anything concerning mortals. Just as we would not be moved concerning ants. But whenever he considers poetry, he follows the stories and makes the subject famous: bringing about alliances and wars among gods.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.526-8.527

Look at the change of mind of Hector. He was speaking to his wife "The day shall come when sacred Ilion is destroyed" (Iliad 6.448). But it is so elsewhere. For there he is despondent because the Trojans were inferior. But here he hopes for good fortune because they are superior in battle.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.153-8.154

First it is not clear if he [Hector] will say [what Diomedes thinks he will], and otherwise he will not persuade them. But he [Nestor] assails to the ones considering what men will say to them. Let them not care what sort of thing it is.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.157

Sensibly, he [Nestor] does not wait for the refutation of Diomedes, nor does he force him, being a lover of honor, to agree to flee. But he turns the horses so that the poet does not lessen Diomedes' honor because of these things.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.167

How having said that Diomedes is divided into two minds, he [the poet] only includes one. But we say that [he is] divided into two plans which converge into one: "to turn the horses and be at war with the enemy." Or that he lets go of the one which is said the same way, rather than to turn or not to turn, which he [the poet] leaves one out.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.377-8.378

Expressively and this regarding the [line] "one who rages beyond what can be endured" (Iliad 8.355). Aristarchus writes προφανεῖα in the dual. But Herodian would rather προφανείσας contracting the alpha in the Doric dialect, by which we are also persuaded.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.349

Aristarchus says οἴματα but the others say ὄμματα. Because he says βλοσσυρῶπις. He [the poet] is accustomed to characterize the face from the eyes. For example "possessing the eyes of a dog" (Iliad 1.225). But Aristarchus writes γοργόνος wrongly. For neither the poet nor Hesiod say γοργὼν but rather γοργώ.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.296
This says εἰρωνευόμενος instead of δεξιούμενος and φιλοφρονούμενος. For it is clear it is δεδεγμένος from δέχεσθαι.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.e3:8.513
The wound from the missile. As in ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ἂν ὠδίνουσαν ἔχῃ βέλος "Just as when the missile grabs hold of a woman in labor" (Iliad 11.269).
